H0.text: The stars are revolving around the Sun, which causes us to see different stars in the sky at different times of the year.

H1.text: The Moon is revolving around Earth, explaining why we see different stars in the sky at different times of the year.

H2.text: Earth is revolving around the Sun, which causes us to see different stars in the sky at different times of the year.

H3.text: The stars are revolving around Earth, which explains why we see different stars in the sky at different times of the year.

A4.text: The Sun appears to move with respect to other stars at a rate of about 1° eastward per solar day.

A5.text: Earth's orbit, also called Earth's revolution, is an ellipse with the Earth–Sun barycenter as one focus with a current eccentricity of 0.0167.
